I don't see this file checked in?
Discarding comment on PS3 as we're at PS16.
probably want unordered_map here?  I suspect that will also remove the need for making SmbusMctpdDevice a shared pointer.
Discarding comment on PS3 as we're at PS16.
constexpr?
Discarding comment on PS3 as we're at PS16.
if you're not passing ownership, you probably want to pass by SmbusMctpdDevice&

Is there a significant difference? Extra derefs?

I'm wary of extracting references from smart pointers. Just feels like a recipe for painful bugs.
Done
Acknowledged

The pull request https://github.com/CodeConstruct/mctp/pull/17/files#diff-222eb3ffb54581db6e3d72a6efa39bf25a8145a7f8eab9b7f4474ea184675da9R2993 also create the Association interface.
This interface will be used in the patch set:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/pldm/+/68347/4/requester/mctp_endpoint_discovery.cpp#29

I don't see the mctpReactor support this association.
Yes, dealing with associations is one of the todos. This patch is marked WIP 😊
Done
Sorry, had a bunch of comments queued that I never sent.  If some of them have been resolved, feel free to immediately close them out.
Haha, okay, that's a lot. I'll work through them.
?  Why declare an auto unnamed variable here?

Replaced with

```
auto toSetup = std::exchange(deferred, {});
```
make a function please
<sobs quietly>
Yeeessss
Should we be consistent with static vs not static here?  I don't really care either direction, but unmanageMctpEndpoint seems like it should take on the same prototype as here.
I might have missed a `static`. I'll check.

nit: This could go for the previous commit and all the functions as well.  I thought generally if we had an acronym we keep it as an acronym.

BMC or bmc not Bmc.
MCTP or mctp not Mctp.

(You can do whatever you want on this.)

This class feels like a lot of code to pretty trivially wrap a map...

Maybe it can be moved to a header file to reduce the noise in this file?  125 lines into the file and I'm still not to anything interesting.
I'll use upper-case acronyms throughout for consistency.

It would be great if there was a bi-directional map in `std`, however there isn't (that I could find). I wrote the class to separate out the logic of the reverse map lookups from the business logic of the `MctpReactor` class. This was a trade-off to avoid a dependency on yet more `boost`.

I'll take your suggestion of moving it to a header to de-clutter the rest of the implementation here.
Done
Done
nit: almost anywhere you use begin/end to the std algorithms you can do `std::ranges:algo(container...`.
Nice, thanks. I'll look at how I can clean this up.
Done
Isn't there only one of these?  I'm not understanding the value of the extra code to put it in a shared_ptr instead of it being a reference.

So maybe I've cargo-culted this a bit. There is only one instance, but its object is referenced by jobs in the boost IO context. To ensure that there can't be any potential lifetime issues I leaned on a shared pointer. Happy to be reasoned out of that though.
Done

Isn't this application purely a dbus client?  Why add a manager (or even claim a busname)?

Oh... later on I see it has associations.
`auto toSetup = std::exchange(deferred, {});`
Acknowledged
Done

This doesn't match the naming conventions for dbus associations.

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/requirements.md#associations
Why is this implied to be a chassis?  What if it is a NIC or an expansion board?

Sure, it needs fixing. I'll need to get a better grasp on how we make it correct though. Do you have references I can lean on?

Regardless, it was just a direct reimplementation of what was proposed here:

https://github.com/CodeConstruct/mctp/pull/17/files#diff-222eb3ffb54581db6e3d72a6efa39bf25a8145a7f8eab9b7f4474ea184675da9R1216-R1221

Right, it was just a direct reimplementation of what was proposed here:

https://github.com/CodeConstruct/mctp/pull/17/files#diff-222eb3ffb54581db6e3d72a6efa39bf25a8145a7f8eab9b7f4474ea184675da9R1216-R1221

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/806f178675aa6499e31a4a0f4b57e6f8f2f2d1ff/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Inventory/Item/README.md#L21

We have a number of documented associations to Items already.  I don't know if 'connected' is appropriate or 'managed'.  We just need to come up with a verb that expresses the relationship.  It can be a verb already in use (I actually prefer we keep the set smaller than trying to make every verb unique).

Quick and dirty set of all association names (though "inventory" is a bad one): https://gist.github.com/williamspatrick/22b4940091a212cb5b9538973119e453
Going to punt this for now so I can address the other comments.
I'm going to punt on this for the moment pending more discussion.

Bikeshedding this some more, how about `configures` and `configured_by` for the relationship between the `MCTPDevice` exposes object and the `mctpd` endpoint object? There's also an opportunity for a `connects` / `connected_by` association between the `MCTPInterface` exposes object and the `mctpd` endpoint object.
Done
Done
nit: I'd prefer this to be MCTPReactor.  The amount of inconsistencies we have is super annoying when trying to debug anything.
Ack.
Done

and yet..... it already does implement openbmc specific logic, and claims an openbmc dbus name.

https://github.com/CodeConstruct/mctp/blob/69ed224ff9b5206ca7f3a5e047a9da61377d2ca7/README.md?plain=1#L72

Can that be fixed?  if it's a generic tool, it needs to claim a codeconstruct name, if it's an openbmc tool, it should be in an openbmc repository.  It really shouldn't be both?

Yes, we've had discussions about acquiring e.g. `au.com.CodeConstruct.MCTP` as the bus name. We'll probably claim both for at least one release cycle. The object paths should be addressed as well.

I'm less concerned about OpenBMC-specific interfaces, though maybe there's an argument for changing those as well.
https://codeconstruct.com.au/docs/mctp-utils-v2-0-release/

My only overall comment is that the application looks a bit chatty from a logging perspective with `info` being the lowest log-level used.  Is all of this really `info` (and for whom) or should some of it be `debug`?

Let me reconsider the log levels.

Just as a note, given the discussion on the schema patch I've ended up chopping a chunk out of the implementation. I was hoping to push updated patches late last week, but got side-tracked.

Would it be possible to get the boilerplate (service file, meson config, empty main() function) into its own review?  I suspect that can merge basically immediately and make this patset more reviewable.

I'd previously had it split in two between the `MCTPEndpoint` pieces and the `mctpreactor` implementation, but Patrick asked me to squash the patches together as it was hard to review without having easy access to use in the same patch.

I realise it's a lot, I just want to avoid flip-flopping over splitting and merging the patch.
maybe std::vector<MCTPDevice> ?
Need the config object path though
Done
Okay, I'll consider that.
But if !fresh is consider error (line 30), should it just do  devices.find(inventory) != devices.end()
Yeah, I'm reflecting on whether an error is right here. If it is I'll consider the `find()` approach.

Okay, so I've had a bit of a think about this and have performed some rework around it. There's now a test case that covers the behaviour, so if there are further queries it should be possible to frame them as suggestions on the expected behaviour.

Marking this as resolved for now.

I see a lot of these operations throw, but nowhere that they're caught?  Admittedly, using exceptions properly in a callback-based async daemon is a challenge, but we should try to make it so a single failure doesn't cause the whole application to crash.  Such behavior in other places (entity-manager mainly) has caused many... many lost debugging cycles.

I'm fairly certain I'm not throwing in deferred tasks, and that I'm catching exceptions in the same call stack, but I'll audit the code for this concern.

Ultimately I want to use [std::expected](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/utility/expected) but we're can't yet set `-std=c++23`.

I've addressed the throws in both `add()` and `remove()` by inspection, and removed the unused `remove()` definition (the latter one above). There's no async task submission in the stack between the exception handling and the throws, so I believe there's currently no concern for blowing up an executor. I've also addressed exception handling shortcomings at the job boundaries (which would have caused the issue you highlighted).

Marking this as resolved for now.

huh?  What's claiming this name?

(answers own question)


https://github.com/CodeConstruct/mctp/blob/69ed224ff9b5206ca7f3a5e047a9da61377d2ca7/README.md?plain=1#L72

so.......  what's the plan here?  I thought the whole point was that the CodeConstuct app doesn't have OpenBMC specific stuff in it?  If it already has openbmc specific stuff in it, why are we writing this app in the first place?

The only OpenBMC-specific bits in it are the bus and object names, and some OpenBMC-defined interfaces are implemented as a defacto standard for certain pieces of information.

As mentioned earlier, the bus and object names need to be fixed to not infer a relationship to OpenBMC. I've already discussed this with Jeremy.
See https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/dbus-sensors/+/69111/comment/1915439d_5d63872f/
This check isn't needed, right?  We already match on interfaces changed at path.
I'll convert it to an `assert()` as it should be invariant.
Done
else log that we weren't able to do the capture.  In theory the only time this should happen is shutdown.  In practice, having the log saves people writing bugs.
Acknowledged
Done
Rename this to `assign()`
Eh, might leave it for now.

This should be `AssignEndpoint`. See discussion here:

https://discord.com/channels/775381525260664832/778790638563885086/1215162914693189702

I think we should keep to use `SetupEndpoint`. When the EID is missed in the JSON, that means OpenBMC does not care about the EID. The endpoint EID can be used if it is existed (static EID, or configured by the BO), if the Endpoint have no EIDs, the mctpd can use the EID in mctpd's pool and assign that EID to endpoint.
That is what current `SetUpEndpoint` does.
We should not assume that the endpoints need new EID then use `assignEndpoint` method.

When BMC is Endpoint in the PCIe interface, the endpoint EID will be set by BO, with the none-configured EID in Json file, the mctpd will used the assigned EID (By BO) for the endpoint and add that endpoint to D-Bus.

Let's walk before we run. The current approach assumes the BMC is the (TM)BO. We can add support for non-BO behaviour later.

If the BMC is a (TM)BO then `AssignEndpoint` is the correct behaviour, as the BO should not be dictated to by the device as to what its EID is, unless it's because of an assignment via a another interface.

Regardless, I suspect there's more nuance to your configuration, and it would be good to have a block diagram of the hardware and bus ownership relationships.
Acknowledged
Typo: `EXCEPTION`
Done
async_method_call doesn't throw, it returns an error to the callback.  I suspect this can be removed.
I'll revisit why I added this.
Done
std::move?
Acknowledged
Done
same here, async_method_call will return an error code, not an exception.
Acknowledged
Actually, this one is required, as we only want to perform the async method call if the match succeeds. Constructing a match can throw an `SdBusError()`, hence the try/catch.
Does this have an effect on the code?
Just upholding the invariant that either the match is installed and all the callbacks are stored, or the match installation fails and no callbacks are stored. Any other combination is unhelpful.
Done
Do these need explicit values?  Maybe just let them be enums without value, to avoid implying that they're a direct map to something else?
The explicit values are the values defined by DSP0239 v1.9.0 Table 3.
Done
at least log these conditions?
What log level do you think is reasonable?
Done
Why?
Because if the inventory is gone then the device has gone with it? There's no point trying to poll it at that point.
Done
non trivial lambda needs rolled into a method.

Maybe my judgement on what is non-trivial needs calibration. The important stuff is in `trackEndpoint()`, the rest is error handling and acquiring a valid `self` reference. It feels awkward to me to be calling a class member function when we don't know if it's called on a valid object (even if the function code won't disappear).
this either returns 0 or 1 entry?  Wouldn't std::optional<uint8_t> be a better choice?
That statement is only true for I2C devices (though admittedly that's all we currently support).
don't we want VariantToUnsignedIntVisitor?  I think that also removes the need for encodeDeviceAddress()

> don't we want VariantToUnsignedIntVisitor?

Does that convert from a string type to an int?

> I think that also removes the need for encodeDeviceAddress()

No, because it's not just I2C physical addresses that we need to care about.
same as above.

this is doing a redundant map lookup.

Do you just want to separate your deviceFor into two methods,

deviceFor (which returns nullptr if the device doesn't exist)
deviceAt (which throws if the device doesn't exist).

This code looks like it's just handling the case where we would otherwise throw.



nit, might also want to log that this happened.  in theory should never happen.

> this is doing a redundant map lookup.
>
> Do you just want to separate your deviceFor into two methods,
>
> deviceFor (which returns nullptr if the device doesn't exist)
> deviceAt (which throws if the device doesn't exist).

Let me consider that.

> nit, might also want to log that this happened. in theory should never happen.

There's a startup race where it could, between registering the signal handler and processing the result of getting the relevant config type.
Done

The fact that we need to do something every 5 seconds is a little scary.  The expectation for reactors is that if there's no config, we're not taking any resources aside from starting and realizing there's no config.

It seems a little odd that this timer is in main.  Couldn't it go in MCTPDevice itself?  That way adding/removing won't have any impact on existing devices, and we won't see blocking behavior where all devices run their logic at the same time.

> The fact that we need to do something every 5 seconds is a little scary. The expectation for reactors is that if there's no config, we're not taking any resources aside from starting and realizing there's no config.

If there's no config the timer callback has nothing to do.

> It seems a little odd that this timer is in main. Couldn't it go in MCTPDevice itself?

Perhaps, but then we're embedding active behaviour deep in the implementation, and that makes testing the code harder. Configuring the timer in main means we can drive time in the test suite on our own terms (so we don't have to wait for a timer to fire in any way). We're externalising time to become an event on a state machine.

> That way adding/removing won't have any impact on existing devices, and we won't see blocking behavior where all devices run their logic at the same time.

I'm not sure I follow what you're getting at there. We only use a single thread, if anything blocks then we're hosed anyway. The DBus calls are async, and on alarm the timer only sets up any known devices that have lost their endpoint.
Done
Doesn't mctpd already implement OpenBMC D-Bus API such as the MCTP.Endpoint?

As a convenience, yes, but you should be aware of this:

https://codeconstruct.com.au/docs/mctp-utils-v2-0-release/
Done

Is the expected entity-manager configuration similar to same as the one in https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/66750? Is the expected configuration (what keys can be in the config, etc.) mentioned in an openbmc/codeconstruct design document?

Are we going to document the configuration D-Bus interface?

EDIT: I see that https://github.com/CodeConstruct/mctp/pull/17#issuecomment-1963187104 answers some of the questions above, but I think it would be good to update the commit message here/or add an openbmc design doc, and document the configuration D-Bus API.

> Is the expected entity-manager configuration similar to same as the one in https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/66750? 

No. That EM change has been reverted:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/70572

> Is the expected configuration (what keys can be in the config, etc.) mentioned in an openbmc/codeconstruct design document?

The new schemas are still under discussion here:

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/q/topic:%22mctpreactor%22+repo:openbmc/entity-manager+status:open
Done

Hi Andrew, I'm working on the upstream plan of SPDM Daemon. It has a dependency on Mctpreactor for getting Eid/Nid info. I'm wondering what's the plan/timeline forward to get this patch merged? Thanks!

At the moment there's no specific timeline, but I do need to address Ed's comments and revise the patch. I'll try to get to that in the next few weeks. Let me know if that works for your timelines. If you think there are issues that are uncontroversial to fix I'm happy for you to iterate on the patch here too 😊
I've addressed a bunch of comments but not yet pushed fixes, that will come shortly (after grinding it through CI locally and testing on hardware).

The yv4 system is like `BMC <-> MCTP_device1 <-> MCTP_device2`. The `MCTP_device1` is served as a MCTP bridge and also a MCTP endpoint. In this situation, The `AssignEndpoint` cannot be send to MCTP_device2.

We observed that there is a command call `Allocate Endpoints` defined in DSP0236. However, it doesn't seem like we can allocate static endpoints.

Do you have any suggestion on this kind of system?
I think that's a matter of improving the support for `Allocate Endpoints` in `mctpd`. I don't think that's a responsibility for `mctpreactor`.
Done
I'm going to merge this for now. Open comments can be addressed in follow-up changes if necessary.
